dataset.title: Exotic Plants and Copperhead Resource Selection Data, Jefferson County, IN, USA, 2008-2011

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology

intellectualRights.para: Acknowledge Evin T. Carter in any publications that use this data.

section.title: Fine and intermediate scale habitat selection data for copperheads at Clifty Falls State Park from June 2008 - November 2011
section.para: Radiotelemetry data for copperhead snakes at Clifty Falls State Park. At the fine-grained scale, data includes densities and heights of native and exotic vegetation within 1-meter diameter plots (fine-grained scale). At the intermediate scale, data includes nearest distance to native and exotic vegetation as well as nearest distance to leaf litter, fallen log (>7.5cm diamter), and rock (>7.5 shortest width) within a 20 meter radius with the snake at the central point. Nearest distance to overstory tree was measured to 40 meters. Distances beyond the maximum are written as the maximum distance plus 1 (e.g., 21 and 41 meters). Snake behavior and position and leaf litter depth in center of plot are also included. Longitude and lattitude oordinates are transformed to protect sensitive locations. Equivalent data was recorded at a paired random location located 20 meters from a snake location in a random direction. Some data collection methods changed between years, most notably from 2009 to 2010. This is apparent in the data. Null text values are denoted as NULL, and null numeric values are denoted as -99999.

section.title: Macrohabitat used and available for copperheads at Clifty Falls State Park from June 2008 - November 2011
section.para: Data describes the proportion of snake locations within the following defined macrohabitats: Heavy Exotic (75-100% exotic vegetation coverage), Mosty Exotic (50-75% exotic vegetation coverage), Semi-Natural (25-50% exotic vegetation coverage), Mostly Natural (< 25% exotic vegetatiion coverage), as well as Anthropogenic (road, residential, lawn). Exotic vegeation coverage was estimated as total percent area coverage in a 30 meter radius along 550 locations spaces 60 meters apart across the study area. The study area is defined as a minimum convex polygon surrounding all telemetered snake locations, including a 40-meter perimeter buffer. Availability of habitat is defined on two separate scales: the landscape level describes total proportion of each habitat within the study area, and the activity range level describes the availability of habitat within a minimum convex polygon surrounding each individual snake. Additional information and detailed maps may be found in:
Evin T. Carter (2012). Impacts of Invasive Plants on Resource Selection and Thermoregulation by the Northern Copperhead (Agkistrodon contortrix mokasen). <http://opus.ipfw.edu/masters_theses/13>

section.title: Leaf depth and exotic vegetation density within 237 one meter diameter random plots at Clifty Falls State Park
section.para: Exotic vegetation was measured as total percent area cover within a 1-meter random plot at sites in the forest interior with greater than 50% canopy closure (measured at four points with a spherical densiometer). Leaf litter depth was measured in the central point of each plot by pressing a 1 cm diameter dowel through the leaf layer.

section.title: Thermal gradient data for estimating thermal set points in copperheads
section.para: We constructed rectangular thermal gradients (200cm x 46cm x 20m) from plywood using metal sheeting and copper coils as a conductive base (temperature range: 18-40 Â°C). Each gradient consisted of a set of ten paired chambers lined with insulation foam, with one paired chamber lighted using soft even fluorescent bulbs and the opposite chamber covered to provide refuge. Tops were constructed from plexi-glass, and a 7.5 cm square hole passed through the length of each gradient in order to provide simple passage between chambers while still maintaining insulation and uniform temperature within each chamber. A thermostat-controlled heat pad was placed at one end of each gradient and chilled water was circulated through copper coils under the opposite ends. The shaded side of each chamber was also heated from above using thermostat-controlled heat pads in order maintain a smooth gradient and uniform temperature within each chamber.

To determine whether upper and lower thermoregulatory set points varied by reproductive state, we outfitted 5 male, 5 nongravid female, and 5 gravid female copperheads with an external temperature logger (iButton, model 1922L, Embedded Data Systems, Lawrenceburg, Kentucky, USA), and each snake was placed alone in the middle of a thermal gradient maintained in a controlled environmental chamber. Body temperature was logged every 10 minutes for 48 hours, and each snake was given an acclimation period of 12 hours in an attempt to reduce potential effects of stress and afford snakes ample opportunity to explore the gradient. For each snake, the 75% quartile (Q3) of all temperatures selected in a gradient was designated as the upper bound, and the 25% quartile (Q1) of all temperatures selected in a gradient were designated as the lower bound.

section.title: Operative environmental temperatures and weather station data at Clifty Falls State Park
section.para: We physical models painted to approximate the reflectance of live copperheads to measure operative environmental temperatures in 18 habitats at Clifty Falls State Park. Models were constructed from 16 cm sections of 2.54 cm diameter thin-walled copper tubing (painted with Krylon light brown #53562). A thermocouple was suspended inside each tube, the tubes were filled with water, and the ends were sealed with rubber stoppers. Models were validated by comparison to both live copperheads and fresh copperhead carcasses (road-killed individuals) by testing each simultaneously in the field for 5-8 hours at both high and low sun intensity. Each model was rotated among and within the 18 macrohabitats every 7-10 days from June 2010 - October 2011. Weather station data was obtained from a local datalogging weather station and later used to predict temperatures in each habitat throughout the duration of the study.

section.title: Operative environmental temperatures at exotic plant invaded and non-invaded copperhead hibernacula during May 2011
section.para: Data represents operative environmental temperatures obtained using physical models of copperheads around 5 hibernacula dominated by the exotic shrubs, bush honeysuckle (Lonicera spp.) and privet (Ligustrum spp.), and 5 hibernacula consisting primarily of native bladdernut (Staphylea trifolia Linnaeus), greenbriar (Smilax spp.), and spicebush (Lindera benzoin Linnaeus) throughout May 2011.

Dependent variable; snake presence and pseudo-absence. Pseudo-absence is based on random locations, which are paired with snake locations by Snake-ID and Time columns. Each random location was situated 20 meters from a snake location in a random direction.
